definition: In or to a foreign country; widely spread.
examples: She studied abroad for a year.
News of the discovery spread abroad quickly.

extra.memory_tip: Abroad = a-‘broad’ world beyond your borders.

definition: Severe mental or physical pain; to suffer great pain.
examples: He spoke with visible anguish. (noun)
Families anguished over the delays. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Anguish = ‘anguish-ing’ pain in heart or body.

examples: The ceremony will commence at noon.
Work commenced after approval.

definition: To praise formally; to recommend as worthy.
examples: The headteacher commended the pupils.
I commend this book to all new readers.

definition: A prolonged public disagreement or heated discussion.
examples: The policy sparked controversy.
They avoided controversy by delaying the vote.

extra.memory_tip: Controversy = ‘contra’ (against) + ‘versy’ (turn) — ideas turned against each other.

definition: Warm and friendly; a sweet fruit drink or liqueur (UK).
examples: They exchanged cordial greetings. (adjective)
Would you like blackcurrant cordial? (noun, UK)

definition: Disagreement with commonly held views; to disagree.
examples: There was little room for dissent. (noun)
Two members dissented from the decision. (verb)

definition: Serious and sincere; a token of good faith (in earnest).
examples: Her apology was earnest. (adjective)
The project begins in earnest next month. (noun phrase)

extra.memory_tip: Earnest = you ‘earn’ trust by being sincere.

definition: To draw out a response or fact from someone.
examples: The teacher’s questions elicited lively debate.
A smile can elicit a smile in return.

definition: A feeling of great excitement and happiness.
examples: They shouted with exhilaration at the finish line.
The flight over the canyon brought pure exhilaration.

extra.memory_tip: Exhilaration = energy that ‘hurtles’ you into joy.

examples: The necklace is made of genuine silver.
Her genuine interest made everyone relax.

definition: A trick intended to deceive; to trick someone into believing something false.
examples: The story turned out to be a hoax. (noun)
They were hoaxed by the fake email. (verb)

definition: To control or influence cleverly, often unfairly; to handle with skill.
examples: The ad tried to manipulate customers’ emotions.
Engineers manipulate data to model outcomes.

definition: To tell a story or describe in detail; a second count of votes or items.
examples: She recounted her journey across the desert. (verb, tell)
The close result led to a recount. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Recount = either re-tell a tale or re-count the totals.

definition: A person who doubts accepted opinions; UK spelling: ‘sceptic’.
examples: A healthy skeptic asks for evidence.
Skeptics questioned the bold claim.

extra.memory_tip: Skeptic = you ‘scope’ claims before you accept.
